subject: Re: [junit] Re: Non Plus Ultra Coverage Measure?
msgSnippet: ... If you measure X then you get X, no matter what X is. If you measure lines of code, you get more code. If you measure branch coverage, you get tests that
messageBody:
>So said javainsel on 2003-05-04 --------------------
>> There are different kinds of test coverage, measured by the
>aspects of the program they cover. 100% line coverage seems to be
>the most definite of the ones you list, although it does not take
>into account different data sets. It is possible to have 100% line
>coverage and still have a defect because you have not written code
>to handle a particular case.
>>
>> I do not like test coverage measurement. It is not smart enough.
>Obviously, 90% coverage is much better than 50% coverage, but the
>return on investment goes down considerably up over 90%. My opinion.
>>
>> Take care.
>
>I have no real practical interest in this. It is theoretical
>curiosity.
>
>You are right with the 100% objection. I meant a measure which
>covers everything. If all tests are written to the results of that
>measure and the tests are all green then I think it is proven that
>there are no bugs in the code (if the test has no bugs itself).

If you measure X then you get X, no matter what X is. If you measure lines of code, you get more code. If you measure branch coverage, you get tests that cover more branches, whether those branches are actually useful is immaterial. That's why I only like one message: Features the Customer Likes that Work.

>Thats what I am looking for. The super duper measure.
>
>Any idea?

No, because Test-Driven Development guarantees sufficiently high coverage, so I haven't found measuring test coverage to be useful. That's just personal taste.

Take care.
